item.title: One paper accepted to ICCD 2025
item.description: One papers was accepted to the International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD) 2025. Our paper proposes FINEA, an efficient neural network architecture exploiting factorized input features. FINEA leverages factorized dot-product operations by exploiting weight redundancy in quantized neural network models. FINEA employs a processing engine that can excutes both factorized and unfactorized dot-product operations. In order to implement efficient factorized and unfactorized dot-product computations, FINEA utilizes filter indexes derived from preprocessed weight tables.

item.title: Taewoon presented at ICS 2025
item.description: Taewoon presented his research work regarding an HBM-based PIM architecture and software optimizations for SpMV kernels at the International Conference on Supercomputing 2025 (ICS 2025). ICS is one of premier conferences on high-performance computing systems. Good job, Taewoon!

item.title: One paper accepted to LCTES 2025
item.description: One papers was accepted to the the ACM SIGPLAN/SIGBED International Conference on Languages, Compilers, and Tools for Embedded Systems (LCTES) 2025. Our paper proposes SSFFT, an efficient and optimized fast Fourier transform (FFT) kernel design approach for embedded GPUs.

item.title: One paper accepted to ICS 2025
item.description: One papers was accepted to the ACM International Conference on Supercomputing (ICS) 2025. Our paper proposes SparsePIM, an efficient HBM-based PIM architecture for SpMV kernels. SparsePIM includes an efficient hardware architecture for SpMV computations and a sparse data allocation scheme in DRAM row. SparsePIM also employ software-base optimizations to balance computation burdens acress multiple bank groups. By combiging hardware and software approaches, SparsePIM can improve SpMV computations dramatically on HBM-based PIM architecture.

item.title: Jihun presented at DATE 2025
item.description: Jihun presented his research work regarding a hybrid GNN accelerator architecture at the Design, Automation and Test in Europe Conference 2025 (DATE 2025). DATE is one of top-tier conferences on design automation, hardware design and architecture. Good job, Jihun!

item.title: One paper accepted to ISPASS 2025
item.description: One papers was accepted to the 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Performance Analysis of Systems and Software (ISPASS). Our paper proposes hierarchical traversal stack design approach using shared memory for GPU ray tracing.

item.title: One paper accepted to DATE 2025
item.description: One papers was accepted to the Design, Automation and Test in Europe Conference (DATE) 2025. Our paper proposes HyMM, an efficient sparse-dense matrix multiplication accelerator architecture for GCNs. HyMM implements a hybrid sparse-dense matrix multiplication dataflow to exploit the data locality observed in graph structures in GCNs.

item.title: Jaewon presented at NVMSA 2024
item.description: Jaewon presented his research work regarding an efficient garbage collection scheme for remap-based SSDs at the 13th IEEE Non-Volatile Memory Systems and Applications (NVMSA 2024). Good job, Jaewon!

item.title: One paper accepted to ICPP 2024
item.description: One paper was accepted to the 53nd International Conference on Parallel Processing (ICPP 2024). Our research paper proposes VitBit, an efficient register operand packing scheme for embedded GPUs. VitBit packs low-precision integer data for parallel computation of integer and floating-point engines. Hence, VitBit can effectively increase the arithmetic density of GPU computations to improve the throughput of embedded GPUs.

item.title: One paper accepted to NVMSA 2024
item.description: One paper was accepted to the the 13th IEEE Non-Volatile Memory Systems and Applications Symposium (NVMSA). Our research work proposes an effieicnt garbage collection mechanism, called ColdMap, which can extend the lifetime of SSD by exploiting multi-page mapping information.

item.title: Prof. Gunjae Koo presented at ICCE-Asia 2023
item.description: Prof. Gunjae Koo was invited to present for one of the special sessions at the IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics Asia 2023 (ICCE-Asis 2023). He made a talk regarding his research on GPU memory subsystem.

item.title: Jonghyun presented at ICPP 2023
item.description: Jonghyun presented his research work regarding an efficient memory controller scheme for GPUs at the International Conference on Parallel Processing 2023 (ICPP 2023). ICPP is one of premier conferences on parallel computing and architecture. Good job, Jonghyun!

item.title: One paper accepted to ICPP 2023
item.description: One paper was accepted to the 52nd International Conference on Parallel Processing (ICPP 2023). Our research paper proposes Warped-MC, an efficient memory controller scheme for modern GPUs. Warped-MC mitigates the latency divergence observed in a warp that create multiple outstanding memory requests. Hence, Warped-MC can effectively reduce a long-tail of load warp execution time to improve the overall GPU performance.

item.title: Jongmin presented at DATE 2022
item.description: Jongmin presented his research work regarding an efficient architectural defense mechanism against transient execution attacks at the Design, Automation and Test in Europe Conference 2022 (DATE 2022). DATE is one of top-tier conferences on EDA and VLSI design. Good job, Jongmin!

item.title: Jongmin presented at ICOIN 2022
item.description: Jongmin presented his research work regarding the new cache side-channel attack mechanism that exploits the vulnerabilities in the undo-based archtiectural defense solutions at the 36th International Conference on Information Networking (ICOIN 2022) held in Jeju-si, Jeju-do, South Kroea. Good job, Jongmin!

item.title: Two papers accepted to DATE 2022
item.description: Two papers were accepted to the Design, Automation and Test in Europe Conference (DATE) 2022. One paper proposes CacheRewinder, an efficient architectural defense mechanism against transient execution attacks. CacheRewinder exploits the underutilized write-back buffer entries to revoke cache updates done by speculative executions. Another paper presents Stealth ECC, a cost-effective and strong memory protection scheme. Stealth ECC exploits not-meaningful data fields to provide stronger error correction capability.
